content: The "Keep Our Homes Act of 2008" includes a temporary deduction for certain mortgage counseling under section 224 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The deduction for qualified mortgage counseling under the "Keep Our Homes Act of 2008" allows individuals to deduct up to $500 for counseling obtained before obtaining a loan on their principal residence. The deduction is not available for counseling on loans not secured by the taxpayer's principal residence and expires after December 31, 2012. The deduction for qualified mortgage counseling under the "Keep Our Homes Act of 2008" allows individuals to deduct up to $500 for counseling obtained before obtaining a loan on their principal residence. The deduction is not available for counseling on loans not secured by the taxpayer's principal residence and expires after December 31, 2012. Certain mortgage counseling deduction allowed by section 224, with a clerical amendment to the table of sections. SEC. 225 introduces a temporary deduction for upside-down mortgages, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. The deduction allows individuals to deduct 20 percent of the excess acquisition indebtedness on their principal residence over its valuation for real property tax assessments, up to a limit of $5,000 per year. Fraudulently obtained mortgages are not eligible for this deduction, and it is not applicable to amounts paid after December 31, 2009. Subsection (a) of section 62 of the Code is amended to include a new paragraph regarding upside down mortgages. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for part VII of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. A new section, "Credit for Certain Home Purchases," is added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The new section "Credit for Certain Home Purchases" allows individuals purchasing a qualified principal residence to receive a tax credit equal to 10% of the purchase price or $7,500 ($9,000 in high-cost areas). The credit is divided equally over two taxable years and is only applicable to purchases made after the enactment of the section and within 12 months thereafter. The tax credit for home purchases is subject to a limitation based on modified adjusted gross income, which reduces the credit amount for taxpayers with income above certain thresholds. The tax credit for home purchases is subject to a limitation based on the amount of tax for the taxable year, and it is a one-time only credit for the purchase of a qualified principal residence. The tax credit for home purchases is limited to the purchase of a qualified principal residence, which is defined as a residence purchased to be the purchaser's main home. No credit is allowed if a credit has been claimed for another home purchase in a previous year. Additionally, no double benefit is permitted if a credit is claimed under another section. Section 1400C states that if a taxpayer disposes of or fails to occupy their qualified principal residence within 24 months of purchase, the remaining portion of the tax credit allowed shall be disallowed. Special rules apply for joint purchases by married individuals filing separately or unmarried individuals. The tax credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence can be allocated among unmarried individuals, with a total credit limit of $7,000. Rules similar to those in section 1400C apply for the purchase and reporting requirements. The basis of the residence is reduced by the amount of the credit allowed. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include section 25E in various provisions related to tax credits for purchasing a qualified principal residence. Section 1400C(d)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include section 25E, in addition to 25D, for tax credits related to purchasing a qualified principal residence. Section 25E provides a credit for certain home purchases, effective for taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act. The amendment is subject to the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001. Additionally, there is a temporary additional standard deduction for real property taxes for nonitemizers. The amendment adds a real property tax deduction for taxable years 2008 and 2009, limited to $500 ($1,000 for joint returns). Eligible state and local real property taxes are defined for this deduction. The amendment adds a real property tax deduction for taxable years 2008 and 2009, limited to $500 ($1,000 for joint returns), with eligible state and local real property taxes defined for this deduction. The amendments made by this section shall apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. SEC. 6. TEMPORARY EXCLUSION OF UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION FROM GROSS INCOME. Amends Section 85 of the Internal Revenue Code to exclude unemployment compensation from gross income for individuals in 2008 and 2009. Effective for amounts received after December 31, 2007.
